questions.question: What is an array in C++?
options: A single variable that stores one value
A collection of values of same data type
questions.explanation: An array is a collection of values of the same data type stored in continuous memory locations. It allows you to store multiple values under a single name, accessed using indices.

questions.question: Which is the correct syntax for declaring an integer array of size 10?
questions.explanation: The correct syntax for declaring an array is: datatype array_name[size]; So for an integer array of size 10, it would be 'int array[10];'

questions.question: In C++ arrays, the index starts from which number?
questions.explanation: In C++, array indexing starts from 0. So for an array of size n, the valid indices are 0, 1, 2, ..., n-1.

questions.question: What will be the valid indices for an array declared as int A[5]?
questions.explanation: For an array declared as int A[5], the valid indices are A[0], A[1], A[2], A[3], and A[4]. The array has 5 elements starting from index 0.

questions.question: Which is the correct way to initialize an array during declaration?
questions.explanation: Arrays are initialized using curly braces {} with elements separated by commas. The syntax is: type array_name[size] = {element1, element2, ...};

questions.question: What happens if you declare int A[] = {1,2,3,4,5}; without specifying the size?
options: The compiler automatically sets the size to 5
The array size is set to 0
questions.explanation: When you initialize an array without specifying the size, the compiler automatically counts the number of elements and sets the array size accordingly. In this case, it would be 5.

questions.question: What are the main operations that can be performed on arrays?
questions.explanation: The main operations on arrays include: Traversal (accessing each element), Searching (finding elements), Sorting (arranging in order), Insertion (adding elements), and Deletion (removing elements).

questions.question: What does traversal of an array mean?
options: Accessing each element of the array one by one
questions.explanation: Traversal means accessing each location of an array one by one, typically for display or processing purposes. It involves visiting every element systematically.

questions.question: Which searching method works on unsorted arrays?
questions.explanation: Linear (or sequential) search works on unsorted arrays. It checks each element one by one from the beginning until the target element is found or the end is reached.

questions.question: Which searching method requires the array to be sorted?
questions.explanation: Binary search requires the array to be sorted (either in ascending or descending order). It works by repeatedly dividing the search space in half.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of binary search over linear search?
options: It is faster for large arrays
questions.explanation: Binary search is much faster than linear search for large arrays. Each comparison eliminates half of the remaining elements, making it very efficient with O(log n) time complexity.

questions.question: In binary search, how is the mid position calculated?
questions.explanation: In binary search, the mid position is calculated as mid = (initial + final) / 2, where initial and final are the starting and ending indices of the current search range.

questions.question: What does sorting mean in the context of arrays?
options: Arranging elements in ascending or descending order
questions.explanation: Sorting means arranging the elements of an array in a specific order, either ascending (smallest to largest) or descending (largest to smallest).

questions.question: In bubble sort, what happens during each pass?
options: The smallest element moves to the beginning
The largest element moves to its correct position
The array is divided into two parts
questions.explanation: In bubble sort, during each pass, adjacent elements are compared and swapped if necessary, causing the largest element to 'bubble up' to its correct position at the end.

questions.question: How many passes are required in bubble sort for an array of N elements?
questions.explanation: Bubble sort requires N-1 passes for an array of N elements. After N-1 passes, all elements will be in their correct positions.

questions.question: What is the key principle of selection sort?
options: Divide the array into two parts
Select the smallest element and place it in correct position
Insert elements one by one in correct position
questions.explanation: Selection sort works by finding the smallest element and placing it in the first position, then finding the second smallest and placing it in the second position, and so on.

questions.question: What does insertion operation in arrays mean?
options: Removing an element from the array
Adding a new element to the array
questions.explanation: Insertion operation means adding a new data item to the array, either at the end, beginning, or at a specific position within the array.

questions.question: When inserting an element at a specific position in an array, what must be done first?
questions.explanation: When inserting an element at a specific position, you must first shift all elements from that position onwards to the right to make space for the new element.

questions.question: What does deletion operation in arrays involve?
options: Removing an element and shifting remaining elements
questions.explanation: Deletion involves removing an element from the array and then shifting all subsequent elements to the left to fill the gap created by the deleted element.

questions.question: How do you declare an array of strings in C++?
questions.explanation: Arrays of strings can be declared as char array[10]; for a single string or char array[10][20]; for multiple strings. An array of strings is essentially an array of characters.

questions.question: What character automatically terminates a string in C++?
questions.explanation: The null character '\0' automatically terminates a string in C++. The compiler automatically places this character at the end of string constants.

questions.question: Which is the correct way to declare a character array for storing a name?
questions.explanation: Both ways are correct. You can explicitly include '\0' or use double quotes which automatically adds the null terminator. Note that for 'GAURAV' you need 7 characters including '\0'.

questions.question: How do you declare a two-dimensional array with 3 rows and 4 columns of integers?
questions.explanation: A two-dimensional array is declared as datatype array_name[rows][columns]. So for 3 rows and 4 columns of integers: int array[3][4];

questions.question: How many total elements are there in an array declared as int A[5][4]?
questions.explanation: A two-dimensional array with 5 rows and 4 columns has 5 × 4 = 20 total elements. Each element is accessed using two indices A[i][j].

questions.question: Which is the correct way to initialize a 2D array?
questions.explanation: Both ways are correct for initializing a 2D array. The compiler treats them the same way, but using nested braces {{1,2,3},{4,5,6}} makes the structure more clear.

questions.question: To access all elements of a 2D array, how many nested loops are typically used?
questions.explanation: Two nested loops are used to access all elements of a 2D array - the outer loop for rows and the inner loop for columns.

questions.question: In a 2D array A[3][2], what are the valid row indices?
questions.explanation: For a 2D array A[3][2], there are 3 rows with indices 0, 1, and 2. Array indexing starts from 0 in C++.

questions.question: What happens if you try to access an array element beyond its declared size?
options: It may cause undefined behavior or crash
questions.explanation: Accessing an array element beyond its declared size leads to undefined behavior. This can cause program crashes, data corruption, or unpredictable results.

questions.question: Which loop structure is most commonly used for array traversal?
questions.explanation: The for loop is most commonly used for array traversal because it provides a convenient way to initialize, test, and increment the loop counter (array index).

questions.question: In the array declaration 'int A[20]', how many bytes of memory are required (assuming int takes 2 bytes)?
questions.explanation: An array of 20 integers, where each integer takes 2 bytes, requires 20 × 2 = 40 bytes of memory in total.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of linear search in the worst case?
questions.explanation: Linear search has O(n) time complexity in the worst case, where n is the number of elements. In the worst case, the element is at the end or not present at all.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search has O(log n) time complexity because it eliminates half of the remaining elements in each comparison, making it very efficient for large datasets.

questions.question: Which sorting algorithm compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in wrong order?
questions.explanation: Bubble sort works by comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order. This process is repeated until no more swaps are needed.

questions.question: In which scenario would you prefer binary search over linear search?
options: When the array is large and sorted
questions.explanation: Binary search is preferred when the array is large and sorted because it provides much better performance (O(log n)) compared to linear search (O(n)).

questions.question: What is the main disadvantage of arrays?
options: They cannot store different data types
They have fixed size once declared
questions.explanation: The main disadvantage of arrays is that they have a fixed size once declared. You cannot dynamically change the size during program execution.

questions.question: Which operation is most efficient on arrays?
questions.explanation: Random access using index is the most efficient operation on arrays with O(1) time complexity. You can directly access any element using its index.

questions.question: In a character array declaration 'char str[10]', what is the maximum number of characters that can be stored?
questions.explanation: In a character array of size 10, you can store a maximum of 9 characters because one position is reserved for the null terminator '\0'.

questions.question: What is multidimensional array?
options: Array that can have more than two dimensions
questions.explanation: A multidimensional array can have more than two dimensions (n-subscripts). Examples include 3D arrays like int A[5][4][3] or even higher dimensions.

questions.question: Which statement about array initialization is correct?
options: All elements must be initialized during declaration
Uninitialized elements may contain garbage values
Array size must always be specified during initialization
questions.explanation: If an array is partially initialized or not initialized at all, the uninitialized elements may contain garbage values (unpredictable data from memory).

questions.question: What is the correct way to find the length of an array at runtime?
options: Arrays don't have built-in length function
questions.explanation: C++ arrays don't have a built-in length function. You must keep track of the array size yourself or use sizeof(array)/sizeof(array[0]) for static arrays, but this doesn't work for arrays passed to functions.

questions.question: Which is true about memory allocation for arrays?
options: Array elements are stored in random memory locations
Array elements are stored in continuous memory locations
Each element is stored in a separate memory block
Memory allocation depends on the compiler
questions.explanation: Array elements are stored in continuous memory locations. This allows efficient access using pointer arithmetic and ensures good cache performance.

questions.question: In the context of searching, what does 'flag' variable typically represent?
options: Whether the element is found or not
questions.explanation: A flag variable is typically used to indicate whether a search operation was successful (element found) or not. It's usually set to 1 when found and 0 when not found.

questions.question: What happens during the insertion operation when the array is full?
options: The last element is removed automatically
questions.explanation: When trying to insert into a full array, an overflow condition occurs. Since arrays have fixed size, you cannot add more elements beyond the declared capacity.

questions.question: Which of the following represents correct array bounds for int A[5][3]?
questions.explanation: For array int A[5][3], there are 5 rows (indices 0-4) and 3 columns (indices 0-2). Array indexing starts from 0 in C++.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using arrays?
options: They provide fast random access to elements
questions.explanation: The primary advantage of arrays is fast random access to elements using indices. Any element can be accessed directly in O(1) time using its index.

questions.question: In bubble sort, after the first pass through an array of n elements, what is guaranteed?
options: The smallest element is in its correct position
The largest element is in its correct position
questions.explanation: After the first pass in bubble sort, the largest element is guaranteed to be in its correct position (at the end). Each subsequent pass places the next largest element in its correct position.

questions.question: Which operation typically requires shifting of array elements?
options: Inserting an element at a specific position
questions.explanation: Inserting an element at a specific position requires shifting all elements from that position onwards to make space for the new element. This ensures the array remains contiguous.

questions.question: What is the space complexity of most array operations?
questions.explanation: Most basic array operations like access, insertion, deletion have O(1) space complexity as they don't require additional space proportional to the input size. They work with the existing array memory.
